{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3552515,"name":"","username":"crazyface","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/67e7ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-10T03:25:18.845Z","cooked":"

Contribute to redlandsrobotics/2025Reefscape development by creating an account on GitHub.

Hi. We are having some issues with our pid. We have a button that moves our elevator, arm, and wrist to a set point. The elevator will go to the point not problems but the arm and wrist quickly jitter before stopping to a really low speed and not moving at all. We tried so many different pid values and the problem persists.

Also another thing to note is that the absolute encoder values for the arm and wrist goes down as the arm and wrist go up, so to make up for that we tried returning a negative speed, and also tried returning an encoder value of 1 - the value, to invert it.

You can invert the absolute encoder so it counts the way you want. Make sure it corresponds to the direction of the SparkMax Relative encoder.

You should run the arm and wrist position loops from the SparkMax Relative Encoders and use the associated absolute encoders to preset the Spark Max encoders on start up.

How many turns of the wrist and arm SparkMax motors are there for one rev of the absolute encoder?
You would use this information to configure the SparkMax encoder position conversion factor.

Split the PID command into 3 - one for each subsystem - and test each individually. Run them as parallel commands for simultaneous motion.

See also Can you override the built-in NEO encoder values with absolute encoder values using SparkMax API? - Technical / Programming - Chief Delphi

Can you share more about the design of your robot? Perhaps a picture? You mentioned “elevator, arm, and wrist”, but there are 1000’s of possible implementations of these types of mechanisms

What absolute encoder are you using? How is it wired?
